messageBody:
Lee Chalupa wrote:

> Thanks for your time Berin. I do appreciate it.
>
> My first assumption is that most programmers use jOptionPane frequently in the GUIs they write.
>
> My second assumption is that these programmers use Junit to test their GUIs including jOptionPane.
>
> Before I go deeper into the details of jOptionPane, I wonder if these are valid assumptions?


I personally work mostly on server side code where GUIs are not used. This is easy
to test.



> If they are valid assumptions, I am curious. Why are my questions about this common approach unanswered or at least
> off the beaten trail? The response I have received leads me to believe that this path is less traveled which leads me to
> believe that I should be using another coding technique/approach that is more common.
>
> Can you help me understand this broader issue?


The question is what are you testing?

JUnit is designed to test functionality and making sure that your classes operate as
expected. It is not designed to be an automated GUI testing framework. It is better
suited for applications where you are enforcing that an algorithm gives expected results
or that no exceptions are thrown for correct input or that the proper exceptions are
thrown for incorrect input.

Personally, I find that GUIs are best tested by humans. This is because writing the
test code for GUIs will take about as much time (or more) as actually writing the
GUI.

What I find effective is the MVC approach (Model, View, Controller). The Model and
Controller code should not have any GUI elements in it. All that is handled by the
View. Let's say that there does need to be some sort of conversational state that
must be taken if the user has to answer a popup dialog.

Let's say we have a delete option in your GUI app. It is a View responsibility to
pop up the "Are you sure?" dialog box. If the user is sure, View calls the Controller
and performs the actual delete function.

Now Let's say we have a more complex example. Perhaps your system has a function
that needs information the first time it is called, but subsequent times no dialog
is needed. The perfect example is the "Save" option. The first time a user clicks
on "Save" for a new document, there is no filename associated with the document.
After that, it is safe to assume that the documents filename is ok. In this case,
the Controller will return an error condition (either a flag in the return value
or an Exception to be thrown) and the View will know that it needs to ask the
user for a filename.

If you properly separate your concerns like this, your Controller code can be
easily tested with JUnit--which is what it is designed for. The same can be
said of the Model.
